awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Workshop on Exuberance of Machine Learning in Transport Phenomena
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is to support the Workshop on Exuberance of Machine Learning in Transport Phenomena to be held on February 10-11, 2020 in Dallas, Texas. The workshop focuses on highlighting the current state-of-the-art and future directions on the application of Machine Learning on transport phenomena research. With the growth of Machine Learning in all areas of science and engineering, we have observed a rapid growth in the number of workshops, conferences, and summer schools all over the world. This workshop is unique in which it brings together national experts from all areas of transport phenomena research to exchange ideas, and to establish a better understanding on limitations and potentials of Machine Learning. 

The workshop program includes invited speakers who will offer their expert views of important directions in Machine Learning, transport phenomena, and their intersection. It will also involve panel discussions on related topics, exploring novel ways to advance the field, and to identify gaps across the curriculum for effective training and education of the future generation of scientists and engineers capable of tackling important problems at the intersection of these two subjects. A Final Report will be prepared at the end of the workshop which will include a summary of the workshop and the major recommendations made by the experts in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to organize a workshop to assess the significance and the potential future impacts of machine learning (ML) in transport phenomena (TPh). Distinguished scholars with expertise in both machine learning and transport phenomena were invited to discuss their recent results and elaborate on future trends and opportunities.  A two-day workshop was organized (www.mltp2020.com) with participation of over 150 researchers from various universities, research laboratories, government and industry.  A total of 11 Invited Lectures, and 32 Posters were presented.  At the end of each day, there was a  panel discussion to concentrate on  challenges, questions, vision and to brainstorm about the potentials and future opportunities in machine learning in transport phenomena and to provide recommendation for National Science Foundations for announcement of future opportunities.


The  outcomes of this project are identification of the paths to be taken in future couplings of ML and TPh for scientific discoveries, computational modeling and simulations. Traditionally, physical modeling has been the used for modeling transport phenomena, however, with the rise of novel deep learning and artificial intelligence, opportunities have been emerged to build more powerful models. With the brainstorm among the mixture of transport phenomena and ML experts, we have come up with the list of intellectual challenges and how ML can potentially overcome those. Transport Phenomena experts talked about unsolved challenges and problems in the field and ML experts gave some possible solutions arose from recent advances in ML. The PIs believe this workshop has set the stage to create new intellectual paradigms in transport phenomena  through its intersection with ML. They also believe that this workshop will spark multiple collaborations across different institutions in the country


Last Modified: 09/14/2020
Modified by: Peyman Givi
